title: Progressive house
text:
Progressive house is a subgenre of <a href="house%20music">house music</a> that emerged in the early 1990s. It initially developed in the <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> as a natural progression of American and European house music of the late 1980s. 
Etymology.
In the context of <a href="popular%20music">popular music</a>, the word "progressive" was first used widely in the 1970s to differentiate <a href="experimental%20rock">experimental</a> forms of <a href="rock%20music">rock music</a> from mainstream styles. Such music attempted to explore alternate approaches to rock music production. Some acts also attempted to elevate the aesthetic values of rock music by incorporating features associated with <a href="Classical%20music">classical instrumental music</a>. This led to a style of music called <a href="progressive%20rock">progressive rock</a>, which has been described as "the most self-consciously arty branch of rock."
In <a href="disco">disco</a> and later <a href="house%20music">house music</a>, a similar desire to separate more exploratory styles from standard approaches saw <a href="Disc%20jockey">DJs</a> and <a href="Record%20producer">producers</a> adopting the word "progressive" to make a distinction. According to DJ and producer <a href="Carl%20Craig">Carl Craig</a>, the term "progressive" was used in <a href="Detroit">Detroit</a> in the early 1980s in reference to <a href="Italo%20disco">Italo disco</a>. The music was dubbed "progressive" because it drew upon the influence of <a href="Giorgio%20Moroder">Giorgio Moroder</a>'s <a href="Euro%20disco">Euro disco</a> rather than disco inspired by the symphonic sound of <a href="Philadelphia%20soul">Philadelphia soul</a>. Prior to the emergence of <a href="techno">techno</a>, artists like <a href="Alexander%20Robotnick">Alexander Robotnick</a>, <a href="Klein%20%2B%20M.B.O.">Klein + M.B.O.</a> and Capricorn filled a vacancy left after disco's demise in America. In the late 1980s, British music journalist <a href="Simon%20Reynolds">Simon Reynolds</a> introduced the term "progressive dance" to describe acts such as <a href="808%20State">808 State</a>, <a href="the%20Orb">the Orb</a>, <a href="Bomb%20the%20Bass">Bomb the Bass</a>, and <a href="the%20Shamen">the Shamen</a>. Between 1990 and 1992, the term "progressive" referred to the short-form buzzword for the house music subgenre "progressive house".
History.
Progressive house emerged after the first wave of house music. The roots of progressive house can be traced back to the early 1990s rave and club scenes in the United Kingdom. In 1992, "Mixmag" described it at the time as a "new breed of hard but tuneful, banging but thoughtful, uplifting and trancey British house." A combination of American, British, Italian, Polish, and German house and techno largely influenced one another during this era. The term was used mainly as a marketing label to differentiate new rave house from traditional American house. Progressive house was a departure from the Chicago <a href="acid%20house">acid house</a> sound. The buzz word emerged from the rave scene around 1990 to 1992, describing a new sound of house that broke away from its American roots. Progressive house was viewed by some as anti-<a href="rave">rave</a> as its popularity rose in English clubs while <a href="breakbeat%20hardcore">breakbeat hardcore</a> flourished at raves. According to DJ <a href="Dave%20Seaman">Dave Seaman</a>, the sound faced a backlash in the early 1990s because "it had gone the same way as progressive rock before it. Pompous, po-faced and full of its own self importance. But basically was really quite boring." The label progressive house was often used interchangeably with trance in the early years. <a href="AllMusic">AllMusic</a> says that progressive house "led the increasingly mainstream-sounding house from the charts back to the dance floors".
Notable early productions.
According to American DJ/producer duo <a href="Gabriel%20%26amp%3B%20Dresden">Gabriel & Dresden</a>, <a href="Leftfield">Leftfield</a>'s "<a href="Not%20Forgotten%20%28song%29">Not Forgotten</a>" (1990) was possibly the first progressive house song. The record label <a href="Guerilla%20Records">Guerilla Records</a>, set up by <a href="William%20Orbit">William Orbit</a> & Dick O'Dell, is thought to have been pivotal in the growth of a scene around the genre. "" in 1994 and "<a href="Northern%20Exposure%20%28album%29">Northern Exposure</a>" in 1996 have both been credited with establishing the genre on <a href="DJ%20mix">mixed</a> <a href="compilation%20album">compilation album</a>s. As well as Guerilla Records, the labels <a href="Deconstruction%20Records">Deconstruction Records</a>, <a href="Hooj%20Choons">Hooj Choons</a> and <a href="Soma%20Records%20%28U.S.%20label%29">Soma Records</a> contributed to the scene's development in the early to mid-1990s. The record label <a href="Bedrock%20Records">Bedrock Records</a> released a series of "Bedrock’s ‘Compiled and Mixed’" albums featuring artists like <a href="Chris%20Fortier">Chris Fortier</a>, <a href="John%20Creamer%20%26amp%3B%20Stephane%20K">John Creamer & Stephane K</a>. Australian artist, Luke Chable has been known for his 2003 seminal remix release PQM’s "You Are Sleeping", titled "You Are Sleeping (Luke Chable Vocal Pass)".
In June 1992, "<a href="Mixmag">Mixmag</a>" published a list that contained what the magazine viewed as the top progressive house tracks at that time.
Stylistic elements.
According to <a href="Dave%20Seaman%20%28DJ%29">Dave Seaman</a>, house DJs who had originally played what was known as <a href="Eurodance">Eurodance</a> borrowed from that the genre. This led to a commercial sound that people associate with progressive house today. Seaman notes that with the various lines between genres having become so blurred that true progressive house is often found "masquerading" as <a href="techno">techno</a>, tech house or even <a href="deep%20house">deep house</a>. As such, the music can feature elements derived from styles such as <a href="Dub%20music">dub</a>, deep house and <a href="Italo%20house">Italo house</a>.
The progressive sound can be distinct from the later <a href="dream%20trance">dream trance</a> and <a href="vocal%20trance">vocal trance</a>. It tends to lack <a href="anthem">anthem</a>ic <a href="refrain">chorus</a>es, <a href="crescendo">crescendo</a>s and <a href="drum%20roll">drum roll</a>ing, but holds an emphasis on rhythmic layers. Intensity is added by the regular addition and subtraction of layers of sound. <a href="Phrase%20%28music%29">Phrase</a>s are typically a power of two number of <a href="bar%20%28music%29">bar</a>s and often begin with a new or different <a href="melody">melody</a> or rhythm.
Later progressive house tunes often featured a build-up section which can last up to four minutes. This is followed by a <a href="breakdown%20%28music%29">breakdown</a> and then a climax. "<a href="Strobe%20%28instrumental%29">Strobe</a>" by <a href="Deadmau5">Deadmau5</a> is a good example. Elements drawn from the <a href="progressive%20rock">progressive rock</a> genre include the use of extended or linked-<a href="Movement%20%28music%29">movement</a> tracks, more complexity and <a href="Human%20self-reflection">reflection</a> but almost always within the <a href="Four%20on%20the%20floor%20%28music%29">four on the floor</a> <a href="rhythm">rhythm</a> pattern.
